This is just a stylistic suggestion: '..., among many others' or 'see in particular...' would seem more respectful than '..., etc'.

'diverge' : diachronic perspective: gradual divergence from a common ancestor.  E.g. Germanic languages are hypothesized to share a common ancestor (= the language of ONE community); and since then, they diverged due to various factors. This does not seem relevant to the authors' point here. Instead, the idea is that languages DIFFER from one another in many respects.  Changing 'diverge' to 'differ' here will also avoid repetition with the later 'diverge' (end of sentence 'diverge in two respects'), which is properly used.

It's not shocking but were best avoided through rephrasing. Then again, it's for authors to choose how formal they want their writing to look. Starting a sentence with § can be among the signs of 'casual' writing, if that is the style that the authors wish to adopt.
This is an adjective > linguistic, not linguistics.

Typical LaTeX issue: opening single quotes need to be 'hard-coded' to come out right. 'Smart quotes' don't work. Here is the correct symbol to use in the LaTeX code for left (opening) single quote: ‘  This needs to be checked throughout.

The conservative / 'purist' phrasing would be 'to one another', because there are more than two. 'These two love each other deeply.' 'Family members should love one another.' (in case there are more than 2) It's partly a question of choice of stylistic register, and that should be left to the authors' choice. But I think intelligibility is concerned, too: there is a pair (English + German) and a set of 3 (three sentences); since reference here is to the sentences, not the language pair, use of 'one another' would definitely be better in my view.  Further below the authors use 'one another', suggesting that they have no entrenched reluctance against it. It would definitely be better to use it here too.
I thought it should be (for predicator),2  i.e. footnote markers after any punctuation.  Footnote marker 1 (a couple of pages higher) is *after* the punctuation (in that instance a full stop).

There are lots of instances of 'e.g.'. Do the authors really want to contrast the first two parenthetical references (citing from longer lists) with the third (only 1 reference)? 'e.g.' is not terribly helpful, as readers may not be able to supply the rest of the list.  Suggestion for authors to consider: remove the 'e.g.' from the two parenthetical references  (Steiner 2008) (Culo et al ... & Steiner 2007)  and assume responsibility for selecting these references as being most meaningful / groundbreaking / well-rounded / interesting to the reader, or other salient qualities.

(i.e. referring not to (1a) but to the next example).  The passage is understandable but requires effort. Recommendation: make things easy for the reader.
There are two references. They should be separated by a semicolon, not ampersand: ... & Burnard 1994; Burnard & Bauman 2007)  Ampersand serves as the separator inside lists of 2 authors.

'In 2012 Basque is located' does not work in English: it would have to be 'In 2012, Basque was located'.  But this phrasing makes it look like 2012 is already pretty distant, and makes readers expect the next sentence to start 'Five years later, in 2017, ...'  Suggested rephrasing: 'As of 2012, Basque was located... It was... There were...' To me, this would sound like an appropriate *present-day* state of the art. The English preterite does not necessarily project events deep back into the past.

first of all, Figures 3 and 4 have apparently been mixed up: the text states that Figure 4 illustrates all ten experiments, whereas it's Figure 3 that has 10 points along the x-axis. (additionally, the Figure 3 caption states that it pertains to the Business domain, but cross-referencing that with Table 5, it's clear that the Business domain numbers correspond to the data points in Figure 4 instead.)  second, here are some suggestions to improve both figures:  - using dual y-axes should be avoided if possible; if it can't be avoided, then both axes should be explicitly labeled within the figure itself (the figure currently provides a legend, not axis labels) - the x-axis should be labeled as well - points along the x-axis are equidistant, as if they represented a nominal / ordinal variable, whereas in reality, they're a numeric variable and should be represented as such (especially if the goal is to highlight correlations) - given that both data series represent corpus sizes, why is one represented using columns and the other using connected points? - English uses a decimal point instead of a decimal comma - the 15.11 improvement is the largest one, it should therefore be the last datapoint on the far right of the plot  this is what the result could look like, if the rest of the authors' original intentions is adhered to: <http://imgur.com/a/SBdT7>

As mentioned before, this is exactly what I'd do to make a bullet point list in Turkish. However, I think a different standard has been established in the English language. Hence, I propose using an opener such as 'This offers various advantages such as / including:', making the first letters of each item lowercase, ending them with semi-colons (except for the second to last, which should be ended with '; and' and the last one, which should be ended with a period. Not an absolute necessity, of course. Merely a suggestion.

column7: Complete review of state of the art?
column8: This statement assumes that the review of the state of the art is complete, but I don't really feel as if this were the case. In my (limited) experience, I know *no* *one* who used Swadesh lists in fieldwork. I know of better lists (about 2,000 items, tailored for a specific linguistic area, and enriched over the years: see https://halshs.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-01068533/ for instance) and the linguists I know use texts to enrich dictionaries. I seem to remember that the idea of people meeting and 'brainstorming' about lexical data (for instance, 'free association' in a given semantic field) has also been suggested, with reports about how that went. There is a database of questionnaires ( http://tulquest.huma-num.fr/en ) with efforts towards reflections about methods.
the type of data collected

This is a highly interesting situation: all remaining speakers being there. It is impressive that this can be achieved. This setting is rather specific, though, isn't it? In other cases, supposing there are several sizeable villages, would you want all the speakers present? With how many participants is it manageable?  The argument about resources can be wielded in various ways. From the linguist's point of view, having everyone present makes verifications and discussion faster than visiting people one at a time. From the point of view of the entire group, it means that 30 people are giving of their time simultaneously, perhaps with some of them 'idling' (having a comment to make / lexical information to provide and not getting a chance to be heard).

It would be good to discuss at least one example. Otherwise the discussion gets really abstract, about empowerment and who makes the decisions, but without an example it's hard to see what it's about.
unless in original, then need '(sic)'

I do not really understand 'when excluding prescribed data collection methods'. Do you mean 'disagreement with this method'? 'Prescribed data collection' would seem to call for more explanation. Would there be a simpler way to say this?
Earlier on you have .1  Here it's 2.  Harmonize (suggestion: footnote number after punctuation: .1, .2)

column7: Swadesh list to build Boasian trilogy??
column8: It seems that there is a big leap from 1st to 2nd sentence.   First sentence: language documentation consists of the Boasian trilogy.  Second sentence: the dictionary is based on a Swadesh list.  As I understand, the Boasian trilogy is a consistent whole: the texts feed into the grammar and dictionary. The dictionary is *not* solely the product of elicitation; much less is it based on a short, 'culture-independent' word list. Boas knew better and would not have adopted this list as a tool, I think.  The reasons why some linguists don't produce big, substantial, beautiful dictionaries is because (i) it takes a lot of time (ii) it's considered as low-level work by some linguists, in view of a hierarchy between The Theory on the one hand and the data on the other. Quote from an Oxford professor, c. 1995: 'In linguistics, the lexicographer is the equivalent of the guy stacking the shelves at Sainsbury's.'   At present (late 2010s), another obstacle is that researchers are encouraged to move from one language to another rapidly, rather than encouraged to go deeper and deeper in the study of one language. If a documentation project on one language is limited to 36 or 48 months, that's too short for a really good dictionary.

General comment: what is it that makes a dictionary good and reliable?  How far can 'the idiosyncrasies of the data' be worked out through public discussion of items, and to what extent does it require real examples from texts?  Dictionary definitions, however carefully worded, tend to be less illuminating than examples from texts. At least, both complement each other. To what extent is 'Dictionary Day' a 'standalone' method? How does it link up with the elicitation of texts?

Strange that historical comparison and typological comparison are put together in the same sentence: 'The comparative method (=diachrony) predates the Swadesh list, but the Swadesh list made this work easier: typologists could use the data for direct comparison'. This is misleading for beginners who are not yet accustomed to distinguishing the two clearly.

The German version asserts the necessity for change, but not that the change will indeed take place. The English version, on the other hand, asserts that the changes will definitely take place. The German sentence is modal, while the English sentence is factual. these terms are not synonymous. Choose one and define it properly, with a reference to the literature.   Most of the German-English examples have a difference in the initial position, which is normally reserved for Topic, not Focus, in both languages. Obviously, there can be contrastive topics in initial position, which are normally phonetically stressed, but this does not confer them focus.   Of course, there are many different definitions of topic/focus, Thema/Rhema, Topic/Comment, aboutness, at-issueness etc. But precisely because of that, it would be good to give clear definitions and situate the terms used here in the wider context of linguistic approaches to focus.

The book titles would look better in italics. As for the English translation of the book title, there are different 'schools': in some styles, English translations are not italicized. To my knowledge, the first Language Science Press book that has this level of complexity for East Asian language references is this one:  http://langsci-press.org/catalog/book/109 (The code for formatting references and the .bib file are all online.) In the style used in that book, Pinyin transcriptions and English translations are all italicized. The order is: Pinyin, then Chinese characters, then English translation.  It may be worth asking Sebastian Nordhoff whether the code for producing the list of references could be adjusted for this chapter (copying the style of book 109) without messing up the other chapters. I would require you to do additional encoding in your .bib file, but that may be useful for all your LaTeX papers so you may as well start doing it now?
As I understand it, all examples which are complete sentences should finish with a punctuation mark - so this applies to all your examples.
What does 'note =' mean? Is the = a misprint?

Strange! New Jersey is a state, not a place.  A bit of searching reveals that the place of publication is:   Atlantic Highlands, NJ  (NJ: state of New Jersey).  In principle, as a proofreader reminded me, this is the correct syntax: all American places should come in the syntax 'place COMMA abbreviation of state'. 'Berkeley, CA', etc. (I found no other place to correct in your references: 'New York' is fine -- 'New York, NY' would be pleonastic and look like a mistake.)
(maybe Berlin \& New York to avoid messing bibTeX code)

column8: de segmentação apropriada a cada língua (Höhle 2009; Mersad et al. 2010). NB many of my comments concern Oxford commas, which sometimes you use and sometimes you don't. I think LSP don't mind whether or not you use the Oxford comma, as long as you're consistent. I've decided to flag the places where you don't use an Oxford comma, so you can add one, rather than the places where you do use one: the Oxford comma is standard in the publishing house and journal style sheets I'm familiar with; and because omission of an Oxford comma sometimes leads to incorrect parsing.

Most software currently created does not take into account the wide array of needs of minority languages. Unicode Exists to support these needs. For instance in FLEx by SIL the data is saved exactly as it is input. Forcing the management of cononicalization upon the users. If we look at most software, most software has a target audience which uses one of 8 languages, also the languages which usually do not require NFD. The acronym 'PVR' is hard (for me): never saw it before. Providing a description that does not match the feature tag really seems asking a lot of the reader ;-) If you call it *postvocalic <r>*, then so be it called at the (few) places where it's explained...?

At another place it's called 'post vocalic <r>'. To me, 'postvocalic' (no space, no hyphen) would look fine; at any rate, please harmonize. Capitalization in the description does not need necessary: even if the acronym (label) is PVC, the description could be simple 'postvocalic <r>' or 'postvocalic /r/'. (Choice between <r> and /r/: the latter seems better: standard in phonology, so maybe stick to that unless there are specific reasons to do otherwise.)

1. Shorten sentences: many sentences are nearly a paragraph long. Since some of the material is dense, it is advisable to shorten sentences as much as possible.  2. Commas: There are commas placed all over the text that should not be there.   3. Center embedding: put adjuncts (whether prepositional phrases or full clauses) nearer to the end of sentences rather then constantly interrupt sentences with center-embedding that make them hard to process. (see Pinker 2014 'The sense of style')

Italics are used in the following cases: • For all object-language forms (letters, words, phrases, sentences) that are cited within the text or in numbered examples (see §10), unless they are phonetic transcriptions or phonological representations in IPA. • For book titles, journal titles, and film titles. • When a technical term is referred to metalinguistically (in such contexts, English technical terms are thus treated like object-language forms), e.g. the term *quotative* is not appropriate here  I call this construction *quotative*.

there is no special capitalization (“title case”) within English titles/headings neither in the article title nor in section headings or figure captions. Book titles in the references do not have special capitalization either, regardless of the usage in the original publication (but English journal titles and series titles do, as these are treated as proper names).

This comment applies to all of the glosses. The original language uses an IPA symbol to indicate a long vowel. This symbol *isn't* a colon, but with small type it looks like one, and in the morphemic glosses the authors are using a colon (as is optionally allowed) for potentially segmentable elements that are not shown in the gloss.   There is a risk that readers will confuse the two, and I wonder whether it is worth using the simpler glossing option (i.e. go.PST rather than go:PST).

That representational constraints can be weaker preferences (more general) or that there is a weak innate preference to put elements into a 'determiner' category (more specific)? [I don't really understand what the latter means, actually].

I think Levshina actually shows that they do, but maybe you are considering the literature she is citing to belong to  cognitive science rather than linguistics. But I'm probably going beyond the proofreader's role here anyway.

Often in sign linguistics, small caps are used rather than full capitalization for sign glosses. This differentiates them from acronyms (e.g., 'NP') but conflates them with morpheme glosses. Small caps are often said to improve legibility. Consider the preferred format.

There is a lot of academic/generic 'we' in the chapter. The guidelines discourage this in favor of singular 'I' for single-authored papers. However, many of the constructions are not easily edited by replacing 'we' by 'I' as they are referring to inclusive readings with the readers. Such re-phrasings may have to be discussed with the editors.

Having already cited the works, a simple mention -- without the link -- will suffice. Also, the use of a simple 'and' here can be confusing, perhaps implying that the two are co-authors. I suggest, 'Both Schwarz and Jenks'.
It's still recommended to not begin a sentence with 'however'. Instead, you might put, 'This is far from being the whole story, however ... '

In my mind, the phrase 'language internal variation' would be appropriate if there were multiple dialects of a language that employed different strategies. What you're talking about, though, might be better characterized as the employment of multiple mechanisms that either (a) make finer distinctions (if they do have further semantic value) or (b) persist in the language nevertheless (i.e., are ossifications of processes that, while they may previously have had semantic value no longer do).
A technical term from a different semantic field. An alternative term might be 'individuals'
unique (=single, i.e., there can be no more than one) or distinct (=not the same individual, i.e., there wil always be at least one man and at least one woman).
A pet peeve of mine -- 'male' and 'female' are biological; 'man' and 'woman' are social. It's the latter distinction that is relevant here, I think.
given
construction used differently throughout text, adjust to either with hyphen or without it
used both with and without hyphen, should be adjusted to either
I think you mean that languages an be grouped broadly into three types. 'those,' then, in the next sentence would refer to languages.
'as well as' (community information is not a sub-part of typological information)
rather, they 'mutually exclude' each other

You might mention some of the more prominent contributions. Also, personally, I would want to see some recognition that Schwarz's approach is not universally accepted and then some references to alternative analyses.
vague and hand-wavy. Better: cite specific investigations of specific languages (i.e., see Author (year) on language, Author .... )
It seems to me that interaction with prepositions is (morpho-)syntactic. This behavior reveals, then, their semantic differences.
My preference is to use italics for a first mention of a key or technical term but to return to standard typeface thereafter.

Your practice seems to be to cite wroks globally/summarily (i.e., without reference to specific pages or sections), relying obliquely on page numbers in examples to point your readers to the appropriate passages. I'd want to see page references in the text.

Your analysis critically depends on a newly-emerging pattern. As I see it, this requires explicit justification, not passing mention in a footnote.
If this is context, it doesn't need to be glossed. If it is part of the example, it should probably be laid out formally.
In my experience, it is not to be expected that speakers have strong/consistent judgements when presented with bizarre contexts.
the leap to part/whole relationships for events needs to be justified.
and, apparently, only these two? I'm still wondering.

It seems to me that you (a) have a shaky judgement on a single, awkward example and you've (b) extended the notion of part/whole from individuals to events without justifying that move.  To me, this just isn't convincing.
Did you test other human predicates? If only these three display the relevant behavior, it is not simply an animacy hierarchy that is at play.

Again, in my experience, it is very difficult to elicit solid judgements on felicity when the example is not 'pragmatically transparent' (i.e., when, as here, it asserts something that is counter to fact).
Do you mean 'simple' (i.e., not compound or complex)?

You still need to establish that what is relevant in (a) is the structure of the NP. The fact that the subject in (a) is likely unique while the subject in (b)  likely isn't makes the two non-comparable.
I don't think this point is critical to your discussion and, as I see it, it's not really defensible. All roles are relational. 'Citizen,' too, requires a town, as do many others.

I believe the order last name, first name is used for all authors, not just the first named.
I believe this is included in parentheses.
I believe a university is treated as a publisher in the case of dissertations. This can be followed by '(Doctoral dissertation).'

You might re-phrase this to make it easier for the reader to parse. Perhaps something like, 'The paper examines the contemporary distribution of the determiner _ni_, comparing it to that of the topic marker, _ba_. It employs Centering Theory to analyze oral materials, concluding that the choice between the two particles is determined by the processing cost of attentional shift.' Honestly, I don't think you say anything more than this, and I fear that your current sentence structure will frustrate your reader.
To what end? I suggest striking.

this is what theories do. It's kind of like saying, 'analysis is performed in order to analyse'. I suggest re-casting this whole section in active language. That will help you avoid grammatical traps and semantic contortions.

A small pet peeve of mine -- linguists anthropomorphize language, talking, for example, about what a language 'wants,' 'prefers' and so on. This habit defers real questions about the ontological status of languages and the agency of speakers, among others. Be that as it may ... The immediate question for you -- and it's important that you be clear on this because you have explicitly invoked twhat we might call the psychological state of speakers -- is who/what performs this operation.
